properties.description: This initiative includes policies that are mapped to the Dutch NBA Baseline. The NBA is used within SURF education institution. Use this as a startingpoint for your security baseline. Preview version please

policyDefinitionGroups.name: GO.01 - Strategy
policyDefinitionGroups.description: An information and cyber security strategy and vision is leading for all activities and measures concerning information security

policyDefinitionGroups.name: GO.02 - Policy
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The organization has adopted a (information) security policy which is communicated to employees (and contractors) via a written policy document or intranet. If applicable, the policy is also actively communicated to suppliers/vendors. The policy is regularly updated, reviewed and approved by senior management.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: GO.03 - Plan - Roadmap
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Business objectives, risks and compliance requirements are translated into an overall information and/or cyber security plan, taking into consideration IT infrastructure and the security culture.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: GO.04 - Architecture
policyDefinitionGroups.description: An enterprise information architecture model (EIAM) has been established and maintained to enable application development and decision-supporting activities, consistent with information or IT plans. The model should make it possible to effectively create, use and share information, in a secure and resilient manner, as required by business objectives and legal requirements.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: GO.05 - Independent assurance
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Independent assurance (internal or external) is obtained about conformity of information processing (including IT) with relevant laws and regulations; the organization’s policies, standards and procedures; generally accepted practices; and the effective and efficient performance of IT.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: OR.01 - Ownership, roles, accountability and responsibilities
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: OR.01 - Ownership, roles, accountability and responsibilities
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Information security is managed at all appropriate organizational levels and security (or information risk management) actions are managed in line with business requirements / risks. Ownership, roles, accountability and responsibilities have been formally assigned and embedded into the organization.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: OR.02 - Segregation of duties
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Roles and responsibilities are segregated to reduce the likelihood of single individuals compromising critical processes. Personnel are only performing authorized duties relevant to their respective jobs and positions.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: RM.01 - Information risk management framework
policyDefinitionGroups.description: An Information risk management framework has been established and aligned to the organization’s objectives and (enterprise) risk management framework.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: RM.02 - Risk assessment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Risk assessments are executed to determine actual risk profiles regarding business objectives. The likelihood and impact of all identified risks are assessed on a recurrent basis, using qualitative and quantitative methods. The likelihood and impact associated with inherent and residual risks are determined per category, on a portfolio basis.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: RM.03 - Risk action and mitigation plan (including risk acceptan
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: RM.03 - Risk action and mitigation plan (including risk acceptance)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Control activities are prioritized and planned at all levels to implement the necessary risk responses, including identification of costs, benefits and responsibility for execution. Approval is obtained for recommended actions and acceptance of residual risks, and ensures that committed actions are owned by the affected process owner(s). The execution of plans is monitored and any deviations are reported to senior management.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: HR.01 - Recruitment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Recruitment processes for personnel are maintained in line with the organization’s general personnel policies and procedures (e.g. hiring, positive work environment, orientation, etc.). Processes are implemented to ensure that the organization has an appropriately deployed (IT) workforce, with the skills needed to achieve organizational objectives. Background checks are part of the recruitment process. The extent and frequency with which periodic reviews on these checks are carried out, is determined by the sensitivity and/or criticality of the function and are implemented for employees, contractors and vendors.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: HR.02 - Certification, training and education
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Education, training and/or experience are regularly verified to see whether personnel have the competencies needed to fulfill their roles. Qualification and certification programs core (IT) competence requirements are defined and, wherever appropriate, qualification and certification programs are used to verify whether they are being maintained.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: HR.03 - Dependence on individuals
policyDefinitionGroups.description: There is a succession planning and staff backup for key/critical individuals and/or departments.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: HR.04 - Job change and-or termination
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Expedient actions are taken regarding job changes, especially job terminations. Knowledge transfer is arranged, responsibilities are reassigned and access rights are removed so risks are minimized and continuity of the function is safeguarded.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: HR.05 - Knowledge sharing
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Transfer of knowledge and skills so end users can effectively and efficiently use the system to support business processes. Knowledge and skills are transferred so operations and technical support staff can effectively and efficiently deliver, support and maintain the system and associated infrastructure.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: HR.06 - Security awareness
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A security awareness program is implemented to educate users about their responsibility to protect the confidentiality, availability and integrity of information (assets).

policyDefinitionGroups.name: CO.01 - Identification and Maintenance of Configuration Items
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: CO.01 - Identification and Maintenance of Configuration Items
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Configuration procedures have been established to support management and logging of all changes to the configuration repository. These procedures are aligned with (and preconditional for) change management, incident management and problem management procedures.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: CO.02 - Configuration repository and baseline
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A support tool and a central repository have been established for all relevant information about configuration items. All assets and changes to assets are monitored and recorded. A baseline of configuration items for every system and service is implemented as a benchmark after changes.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: IM.01 - Incident management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A formal incident management process is communicated and implemented. Procedures are in place to ensure that all incidents and failures are recorded, analyzed, categorized and prioritized according to impact. All incidents are tracked and periodically reviewed to ensure they are resolved in a timely manner.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: IM.02 - Incident escalation
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Incident management (or service desk) procedures are established so, if incidents cannot be resolved within the agreed period, service levels are appropriately escalated and, if appropriate, workarounds are provided. Incident ownership and life cycle monitoring remain with the service desk for user-based incidents, regardless which IT group is working on resolution activities

policyDefinitionGroups.name: IM.03 - Incident response on (cyber) security incidents
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: IM.03 - Incident response on (cyber) security incidents
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The organization has an incident response capability to detect (cyber) security incidents quickly, contain them, mitigate impact, and restore and reconstitute services in a trusted manner.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: IM.04 - Problem management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A formal problem management process has been defined and implemented. Procedures are in place to identify (proactively & reactively) causes of (potential) incidents and problems, and to control known errors until they are resolved. Structural errors in IT-services are minimized, whereby reducing the number and impact of potential problems.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: CH.01 - Change standards and procedures
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Formal change management procedures have been set up to handle all requests (including maintenance and patches) for changes to applications, procedures, processes, system and service parameters, and the underlying platforms, in a standardized manner.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: CH.02 - Impact assessment, prioritization and authorization
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: CH.02 - Impact assessment, prioritization and authorization
policyDefinitionGroups.description: All change requests are assessed in a structured manner to determine impact on the operational system and its functionality. All changes are categorized, prioritized and authorized.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: CH.03 - Emergency changes
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Emergency changes requiring immediate implementation are properly handled to ensure minimal impact to systems and IT applications. The emergency change is registered, evaluated and tested after implementation and approved by senior management.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: CH.04 - Test environment
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A secure test environment has been defined and established, which represents the planned production environment in terms of security, internal controls, operational practices, data quality, privacy requirements and workloads.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: CH.05 - Testing of changes
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Changes are tested independently in accordance with the defined test plan prior to migration to the operational environment. It is ensured that the plan considers security and performance.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: CH.06 - Promotion to production
policyDefinitionGroups.description: After testing, handover of the changed system to operations is controlled, keeping it in line with the implementation plan. Approval is obtained from key stakeholders, such as users, system owner and operational management. Wherever appropriate, the system is run parallel to the old system for a while, and behavior and results are compared.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SD.01 - Methodology for secure development and implementation of
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: SD.01 - Methodology for secure development and implementation of software
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A structured approach (secure software development life cycle process) to in-house development and acquisition of software is in place, which ensures that potential risks to internal controls are adequately assessed and mitigated, and that confidentiality, integrity and availability aspects are addressed. For each new development or acquisition, approval is required by an appropriate level of business and IT management.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SD.02 - Developer access to production
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Employees (developers) involved in the development and implementation of changes to in-scope applications and supporting operating systems and databases are restricted from having write-level access to the production environment. The employees (developers) responsible for releasing the source code to production do not have write-level access to the test or development environment.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SD.03 - Data conversion and-or migration
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Management has controls in place to ensure that data conversion (relevant to financial reporting) is accurate and complete, and data conversion controls are designed by the entity to maintain the integrity of data throughout the conversion process.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: DM.01 - Data (and system) ownership
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The business is provided with procedures and tools, enabling it to address its responsibilities for ownership of data and information systems. Owners make decisions about classifying information and (information)systems and protect them in line with this classification.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: DM.02 - Classification
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Establish a classification scheme that applies throughout the organization, based on the criticality and sensitivity (e.g., public, confidential, top secret) of organization data. This scheme includes details about data ownership; definition of appropriate (information)security levels and protection controls; and a brief description of data retention and destruction requirements, criticality and sensitivity. It is used as the basis for applying controls such as access controls, archiving and encryption.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: DM.03 - Security requirements for data management
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: DM.03 - Security requirements for data management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Policies and procedures are defined and implemented to identify and apply (information)security requirements applicable to the receipt, processing, storage and output of data in order to meet business objectives, the organization’s (information)security policy and regulatory requirements (e.g. data privacy).

policyDefinitionGroups.name: DM.04 - Storage and retention arrangements
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Procedures are defined and implemented for effective and efficient data storage, retention and archiving to meet business objectives, the organization’s (information)security policy and regulatory requirements.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: DM.05 - Exchange of (sensitive) data
policyDefinitionGroups.description: (Cyber)policies and procedures are defined and implemented to ensure that business requirements for the protection of data and software are met when data and software are exchanged within the organization or with any external entity. Sensitive transaction data is only exchanged via a trusted path or medium with (cyber)controls to show authenticity of content, proof of submission, proof of receipt and non-repudiation of origin.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: DM.06 - Disposal
policyDefinitionGroups.description: (Cyber)procedures are defined and implemented to ensure that business requirements for protecting (sensitive) data and software are met when data and hardware are disposed of or transferred.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: ID.01 - Access rules
policyDefinitionGroups.description:
The organization has defined access groups (or roles) based upon established business rules, including segregation of duties, in a SOLL authorization matrix.
Procedures are in place to ensure timely initiation and update in the SOLL authorization matrices for all assets. Management authorizes changes to defined privileges for access groups (or roles).
All user activities can be traced to uniquely identifiable users (for instance based on combination of userid and password or token or biometrical information).

policyDefinitionGroups.name: ID.02 - Access rights administration
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Employee access rights are assigned commensurate with assigned job responsibilities (e.g. through role-based access). Administration procedures are available to define activities for requesting, issuing or closing an account and its associated user access rights. The procedure addresses the method used by senior management to appropriately authorize these activities. Access to information is based on 'need-to-know/need-to-have'-principle.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: ID.03 - Super users
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Management has controls in place which ensure that super user access is restricted to an appropriate (limited) group of individuals and that activities performed with super user accounts are monitored. Super user accounts need to be approved by responsible management.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: ID.04 - Envelope procedure
policyDefinitionGroups.description: An envelope procedure has been defined to control emergency access to accounts with super user rights and is followed by the organization.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: ID.05 - Periodic review of access rights
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: ID.05 - Periodic review of access rights
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Management periodically reviews user access implemented for the relevant applications (IST-situation) in order to confirm the correctness of implemented accounts and roles (the access rights), and validate that access rights are commensurate with assigned job responsibilities, as set out by the access rules (SOLL-situation). Any inappropriate access noted during the review process is revoked in a timely manner. This control involves SOLL and IST matrices being compared by responsible management.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.01 - Security baselines
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Security baselines and guidelines for IT infrastructure are in place to limit the risk of unauthorized access to IT assets. Security baselines are formally defined, periodically updated and reviewed, approved by senior management, and communicated to responsible IT staff.  Implemented security settings for IT assets are periodically reviewed for compliance with security baselines. Deviations from the baselines are documented and approved.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.02 - Authentication mechanisms
policyDefinitionGroups.description:
All users (internal, external and temporary) and their activity on IT systems should be uniquely identifiable. 
Management is responsible for periodically reviewing the list of active IDs in relevant applications, in order to validate whether unique User ID's are implemented to provide individual accountability and to ensure that generic or system level IDs are locked or otherwise protected. Any inappropriate or inactive IDs noted during the review process are disabled in a timely manner.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.03 - Mobile devices and teleworking
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Ensuring information security when using mobile devices and teleworking facilities. Mobile device management, encryption and malware protection are in place to limit the risks.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.04 - Logging
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Logging requirements are defined based on monitoring and reporting needs, and implemented in systems, databases and network components. Logs are periodically reviewed for indications of inappropriate or unusual activities, and adequate follow-up actions are defined. Log retention and access rights are in line with business requirements.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.05 - Security testing, surveillance and monitoring
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: SM.05 - Security testing, surveillance and monitoring
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Implementation of IT security is tested and monitored in a proactive way. IT security is reaccredited in a timely manner to ensure that the organization's approved information security baseline is maintained. A logging and monitoring function enables early prevention and/or detection and subsequent timely reporting of unusual and/or abnormal activities which needs to be addressed.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.06 - Patch management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Available patches and/or security fixes are installed in compliance with set and approved policies (including those for operating systems, databases and installed applications) and recommendations of CERT and/or suppliers.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.07 - Threat and vulnerability management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A threat and vulnerability management process is implemented to identify threats and timely detect and remedy vulnerabilities that may lead to a degradation in performance of, or an attack on, an enterprise resource. The number of attack vectors is also in scope, thus reducing the overall exposure.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.08 - Infrastructure resource protection and availability
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: SM.08 - Infrastructure resource protection and availability
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Internal control, security and auditability measures are implemented during the configuration, integration and maintenance of hardware and infrastructure software to protect resources and ensure availability and integrity. Responsibilities for using sensitive infrastructure components are clearly defined and understood by those who develop and integrate infrastructure components. Their use is monitored and evaluated.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.09 - Infrastructure maintenance
policyDefinitionGroups.description: A strategy and plan for infrastructure maintenance has been developed, and ensures that changes are controlled in line with the organization’s change management procedure. Include periodic reviews against business needs, patch management, upgrade strategies, risks, vulnerability assessment and security requirements.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.10 - Cryptographic key management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Policies and procedures are in place to organize the generation, change, revocation, destruction, distribution, certification, storage, entry, use and archiving of cryptographic keys to protect keys against modification and unauthorized disclosure.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.11 - Network security
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Security techniques and related management procedures (e.g., firewalls, security appliances, network segmentation and intrusion detection) are used to authorize access and control information flows from and to networks. Available best practices in this area (i.e. GovCert, ISO/IEC, ITSec) are considered.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.12 - Manage malware attacks
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Preventive, detective and corrective measures are in place (especially up-to-date security patches and virus control) across the organization to protect information systems and technology from malware (e.g., viruses, worms, spyware, spam).

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SM.13 - Protection of security technology
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Security-related technology has been made resistant to tampering, and security documentation is not disclosed unnecessarily.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: PH.01 - Physical security measures
policyDefinitionGroups.description:
For workplaces, the organization has defined and implemented physical security measures in line with business requirements to ensure that access to information systems is appropriately restricted and is capable of effectively preventing, detecting and mitigating risks relating to theft, temperature, fire, smoke water vibration, terror, vandalism, power outages, chemicals or explosives.
Access to premises, buildings and areas should be justified, authorized, logged and monitored. This applies to all persons entering the premises, including staff, temporary staff, clients, vendors, visitors or any other third party.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: PH.02 - Physical access rights management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Procedures are defined and followed to grant, limit and revoke access to IT-critical areas or data centers (e.g. premises, buildings and rooms) according to business needs, including emergency access. Adequate security measures (e.g., lock on door, card-key access system, cipher lock, etc.) are used to restrict physical access to computer facilities that house relevant applications.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: OP.01 - Job processing
policyDefinitionGroups.description:
The organization has procedures in place for automated job scheduling. Job operations are monitored and include:
- the use of interfaces between relevant systems to confirm that data transmissions are complete, accurate and valid.
- results of the backup job to confirm success
Failures are recorded and resolved via the incident management procedure. The ability to modify job schedules, batch jobs and automated interfaces is restricted to authorized individuals.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: OP.02 - Backup and recovery  procedures
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The organization has implemented a strategy for regularly backing up relevant data and programs. Backup and recovery procedures are formally defined and implemented for all in-scope systems. The backup schedule and retention requirements are in line with the risks accepted by the business for data loss and based on the criticality of the system and the cost of manual recovery. Periodic testing for restore procedures is executed and documented.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: OP.03 - Capacity and performance management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The organization has procedures implemented to ensure that the performance and capacity of IT services and the IT infrastructure is able to deliver the agreed service level targets in a cost effective and timely manner. Performance and capacity management considers all resources required to deliver the IT service, and plans for short, medium and long term business requirements, including forecasting future needs based on workload, storage and contingency requirements.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: BC.01 - Business continuity planning
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Business and IT continuity plans are developed based on the framework and designed to reduce the impact of a major disruption on key business functions and processes. The plans are based on risk-related understanding about potential business impacts and address requirements concerning resilience, alternative processing and recovery capability in all critical IT services. The plans also cover usage guidelines, roles and responsibilities, procedures, communication processes and the testing method.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: BC.02 - Testing of Disaster recovery
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Business and IT continuity plans are tested on a regular basis to ensure that business critical systems and services can be effectively recovered, shortcomings are addressed and the plan remains relevant. This requires careful preparation, documentation, reporting of test results and, depending on the results, implementation of an action plan. The extent of testing recovery in single applications ranges from integrated testing scenarios to end-to-end testing and integrated vendor testing.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: BC.03 - Off site backup storage
policyDefinitionGroups.description: All critical backup media, documentation and other IT resources needed for IT recovery and business continuity plans are stored offsite. The content of backup storage is determined after collaboration between business process owners and IT personnel. Management at the offsite storage facility acts on the basis of data classification policy and the enterprise’s media storage practices. IT management ensures that offsite arrangements are periodically assessed, at least annually, for content, environmental protection and security. Compatibility of hardware and software for restoring archived data is ensured, and archived data is periodically tested and refreshed.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: BC.04 - Data replication
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Data replication has been set up between the organization's production facility and its disaster recovery facility to help ensure that critical financial and operational data is available on short notice. Replication status is monitored as part of the system jobs monitoring process.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: BC.05 - Crisis management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The organization needs to have a crisis management capability to respond to accidents promptly, thoroughly and in a coordinated manner to mitigate impact and restore services in a timely fashion.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SC.01 - Service level agreement
policyDefinitionGroups.description: IT services provided to the entity are defined in the contract and underlying SLA. Measures have been taken to ensure that services meet the organization's current and future needs.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SC.02 - Service level management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Business requirements, and the way in which IT-enabled services and service levels support business processes, are periodically analyzed. Services and service levels are discussed and agreed with the business, and compared with the current service portfolio to identify new or changed services or service level options.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SC.03 - Supplier risk management
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Risks are continuously identified and mitigated relating to suppliers’ ability to continue effective service delivery in a secure and efficient manner. Contracts comply with universal business standards in accordance with legal and regulatory requirements. Risk management considers non-disclosure agreements (NDAs), escrow contracts, continued supplier viability, conformance with security requirements, alternative suppliers, penalties and rewards, etc.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: SC.04 - Internal control at third parties
policyDefinitionGroups.displayName: SC.04 - Internal control at third parties
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The status of external service providers’ internal controls is assessed. Procedures are in place to ensure that external service providers comply with legal and regulatory requirements and contractual obligations.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:A maximum of 3 owners should be designated for your subscription
metadata.description: Enable or disable the execution of the policy

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:There should be more than one owner assigned to your subscription
metadata.description: Enable or disable the execution of the policy

metadata.displayName: Include Arc connected servers for Guest Configuration policies
metadata.description: Optionally choose to audit settings inside Arc connected servers using Guest Configuration policies. By selecting this option, you agree to be charged monthly per Arc connected machine.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Audit Windows machines that do not have the password complexity setting enabled
metadata.description: Enable or disable the execution of this policy

metadata.displayName: Maximum password age
metadata.description: The Maximum password age setting determines the period of time (in days) that a password can be used before the system requires the user to change it.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Audit Windows machines that do not have the maximum password age set to specified number of days
metadata.description: Enable or disable the execution of this policy

metadata.displayName: Minimum password age
metadata.description: The Minimum password age setting determines the period of time (in days) that a password must be used before the user can change it.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Audit Windows machines that do not have the minimum password age set to specified number of days
metadata.description: Enable or disable the execution of this policy

metadata.displayName: Minimum password length
metadata.description: The Minimum password length setting determines the least number of characters that can make up a password for a user account.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Audit Windows machines that do not restrict the minimum password length to specified number of characters
metadata.description: Enable or disable the execution of this policy

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:SQL databases should have vulnerability findings resolved
metadata.description: Enable or disable the execution of the policy

metadata.displayName: Enforce password history

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Audit Windows machines that allow re-use of the passwords after the specified number of unique passwords

metadata.displayName: Status if Windows Defender is not available on machine
metadata.description: Windows Defender Exploit Guard is only available starting with Windows 10/Windows Server with update 1709. Setting this value to 'Non-Compliant' shows machines with older versions on which Windows Defender Exploit Guard is not available (such as Windows Server 2012 R2) as non-compliant. Setting this value to 'Compliant' shows these machines as compliant.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes clusters should be accessible only over HTTPS
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the resource creation. 'Disable' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Namespace exclusions
metadata.description: List of Kubernetes namespaces to exclude from policy evaluation. System namespaces "kube-system", "gatekeeper-system" and "azure-arc" are always excluded by design. "azure-extensions-usage-system" is optional to remove.

metadata.displayName: Namespace inclusions
metadata.description: List of Kubernetes namespaces to only include in policy evaluation. An empty list means the policy is applied to all resources in all namespaces.

metadata.displayName: Kubernetes label selector
metadata.description: Label query to select Kubernetes resources for policy evaluation. An empty label selector matches all Kubernetes resources.

schema.description: A label selector is a label query over a set of resources. The result of matchLabels and matchExpressions are ANDed. An empty label selector matches all resources.

matchLabels.description: matchLabels is a map of {key,value} pairs.

matchExpressions.description: matchExpressions is a list of values, a key, and an operator.

key.description: key is the label key that the selector applies to.

operator.description: operator represents a key's relationship to a set of values.

values.description: values is an array of string values. If the operator is In or NotIn, the values array must be non-empty. If the operator is Exists or DoesNotExist, the values array must be empty.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster containers should only use allowed images
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the resource creation. 'Disable' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Allowed registry or registries regex
metadata.description: The RegEx rule used to match allowed container image field in a Kubernetes cluster. For example, to allow any Azure Container Registry image by matching partial path: ^[^\/]+\.azurecr\.io\/.+$ and for multiple registries: ^([^\/]+\.azurecr\.io|registry\.io)\/.+$

metadata.displayName: Containers exclusions
metadata.description: The list of InitContainers and Containers to exclude from policy evaluation. The identify is the name of container. Use an empty list to apply this policy to all containers in all namespaces.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster should not allow privileged containers
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the resource creation. 'Disable' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Image exclusions
metadata.description: The list of InitContainers and Containers to exclude from policy evaluation. The identifier is the image of container. Prefix-matching can be signified with `*`. For example: `myregistry.azurecr.io/istio:*`. It is recommended that users use the fully-qualified Docker image name (e.g. start with a domain name) in order to avoid unexpectedly exempting images from an untrusted repository.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster services should listen only on allowed ports
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the resource creation. 'Disable' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Allowed service ports list in Kubernetes cluster
metadata.description: The list of service ports allowed in a Kubernetes cluster. Array only accepts strings. Example: ["443", "80"]

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster containers CPU and memory resource limits should not exceed the specified limits
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the resource creation. 'Disable' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Max allowed CPU units in Kubernetes cluster
metadata.description: The maximum CPU units allowed for a container. E.g. 200m. For more information, please refer https://aka.ms/k8s-policy-pod-limits

metadata.displayName: Max allowed memory bytes in Kubernetes cluster
metadata.description: The maximum memory bytes allowed for a container. E.g. 1Gi. For more information, please refer https://aka.ms/k8s-policy-pod-limits

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster pods and containers should only run with approved user and group IDs
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created or updated, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the non-compliant resource creation or update. 'Disabled' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Run as user rule
metadata.description: The 'RunAsUser' rule that containers are allowed to run with. MustRunAs requires at least one range to be specified. MustRunAsNonRoot requires the pod be submitted with non-zero runAsUser or have USER directive defined (using a numeric UID) in the image. RunAsAny allows any runAsUser to be specified

metadata.displayName: Allowed user ID ranges
metadata.description: The user ID ranges that are allowed for containers to use. Set 'max' as '-1' to skip max limit evaluation. Empty array blocks every defined value for 'MustRunAs'.

metadata.displayName: Run as group rule
metadata.description: The 'RunAsGroup' rule that containers are allowed to run with. MustRunAs requires at least one range to be specified. MayRunAs does not require that 'RunAsGroup' be specified. RunAsAny allows any

metadata.displayName: Allowed group ID ranges
metadata.description: The group ID ranges that are allowed for containers to use. Set 'max' as '-1' to skip max limit evaluation. Empty array blocks every defined value for 'MustRunAs' and 'MayRunAs'.

metadata.displayName: Supplemental group rule
metadata.description: The 'SupplementalGroups' rule that containers are allowed to run with. MustRunAs requires at least one range to be specified. MayRunAs does not require that 'SupplementalGroups' be specified. RunAsAny allows any

metadata.displayName: Allowed supplemental group ID ranges
metadata.description: The supplemental group ID ranges that are allowed for containers to use. Set 'max' as '-1' to skip max limit evaluation. Empty array blocks every defined value for 'MustRunAs' and 'MayRunAs'.

metadata.displayName: File system group rule
metadata.description: The 'FSGroup' rule that containers are allowed to run with. MustRunAs requires at least one range to be specified. MayRunAs does not require that 'FSGroup' be specified. RunAsAny allows any

metadata.displayName: Allowed file system group ID ranges
metadata.description: The file system group ranges that are allowed for pods to use. Set 'max' as '-1' to skip max limit evaluation. Empty array blocks every defined value for 'MustRunAs' and 'MayRunAs'.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes clusters should not allow container privilege escalation
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created or updated, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the non-compliant resource creation or update. 'Disabled' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster containers should not share host process ID or host IPC namespace
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created or updated, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the non-compliant resource creation or update. 'Disabled' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster containers should run with a read only root file system

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster containers should only use allowed capabilities
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created or updated, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the non-compliant resource creation or update. 'Disabled' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Allowed capabilities
metadata.description: The list of capabilities that are allowed to be added to a container. Provide empty list as input to block everything.

metadata.displayName: Required drop capabilities
metadata.description: The list of capabilities that must be dropped by a container.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster containers should only use allowed AppArmor profiles
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created or updated, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the non-compliant resource creation or update. 'Disabled' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Allowed AppArmor profiles
metadata.description: The list of AppArmor profiles that containers are allowed to use. E.g. [ "runtime/default", "docker/default" ]. Provide empty list as input to block everything.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster pods should only use approved host network and port range
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created or updated, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the non-compliant resource creation or update. 'Disabled' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Allow host network usage
metadata.description: Set this value to true if pod is allowed to use host network otherwise false.

metadata.displayName: Min host port
metadata.description: The minimum value in the allowable host port range that pods can use in the host network namespace.

metadata.displayName: Max host port
metadata.description: The maximum value in the allowable host port range that pods can use in the host network namespace.

metadata.displayName: Effect for policy:Kubernetes cluster pod hostPath volumes should only use allowed host paths
metadata.description: 'Audit' allows a non-compliant resource to be created or updated, but flags it as non-compliant. 'Deny' blocks the non-compliant resource creation or update. 'Disabled' turns off the policy.

metadata.displayName: Allowed host paths
metadata.description: The host paths allowed for pod hostPath volumes to use. Provide an empty paths list to block all host paths.
